Tomorrow, nearly 100 million Mexicans will cast their votes to elect a new president. While most eyes are on the upcoming U.S. presidential election, this pivotal event in Mexico could significantly impact American interests. Here's why the U.S. Congress needs to stay informed:

ğŸ’µ Remittances: The $63.3 billion sent to Mexico from the U.S. in 2023 sustains the Mexican economy. Economic growth in Mexico could reduce this dependency.

Dr. Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo speaking at rally in Los Angeles last year. | Fight Back! News/staff

Los Angeles, CA â€“ The historic June 2 elections in Mexico resulted in a win for Dr. Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo of the MORENA party as the countryâ€™s first female president. Dr. Sheinbaum Pardo studied engineering and environmental science and was previously mayor of Mexico City. Her parents were activists in the 1960s student movement. She vows to continue the MORENA political program.

Mexicans turned out in large numbers for elections for president, state governors, congress and local municipal positions. Early results show Dr. Sheinbaum ahead with 60% of the vote. The MORENA Party won a majority in congress. The elections are considered fair and democratic as observers did not find any irregularities except for some incidents of violence at polling sites.

In the U.S., Mexican embassies were overwhelmed by thousands wanting to vote but unable to, due to lack of ballots.

The electoral alliance of MORENA (National Regeneration Movement) , PT (Workers Party) and PVEM (Environmental Party) won its second presidential campaign.

The current president and founder of MORENA, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, also known by his initials AMLO, represents a progressive nationalist movement. Six years ago, MORENA defeated the right-wing conservative, pro-capitalist parties PRI/PAN. The PRI/PAN parties in the past had privatized major Mexican industries such as oil, electricity and railroads. They pushed the neoliberal agenda of privatization and fewer public services, and fostered corruption by working with the powerful drug cartels.

Mexicoâ€™s official electoral authority said preliminary results showed the 61-year-old former mayor of Mexico City winning between 58% and 60% of the vote in Sundayâ€™s election.

Sheinbaum will replace her mentor, outgoing President #AndrÃ©sManuelLÃ³pezObrador, on the 1st of October.
Prior to running for president, Sheinbaum was mayor of Mexico City, one of the most influential political positions in the country and one that is seen as paving the way for the presidency.

The 61-year old #climatescientist was part of the U.N.
Intergovernmental Panel on #ClimateChange team that would go on to share a Nobel Peace Prize with former U.S.
Vice President Al Gore in 2007.
Both of her parents were scientists and Sheinbaum studied physics before going on to receive a doctorate in energy engineering. 

She spent years at a renown research lab in California studying Mexican energy consumption patterns and became an expert on climate change.
That experience and her student activism eventually earned her the position of secretary of the environment for Mexico City at the time when AndrÃ©s Manuel Lopez Obrador was mayor of the capital.

In 2018 she became the first female mayor of Mexico City, a post she held until 2023, when she stepped down to run for president.

Ruling party candidate Claudia Sheinbaum won Mexico's presidential election, according to the INE electoral institute's rapid sample count released Sunday night.

The electoral institute's so-called rapid count estimates the result of the election based on a sample that is representative of the vote across the country. It has a margin of error of +/-1.5%, INE says.

Kepala Lembaga Pemilu Nasional Meksiko mengabarkan sampel statistik wakil dari seluruh negeri menunjukkan kandidat dari partai populis sayap kiri Morena ini memenangkan antara 58,3 persen hingga 60,7 persen suara.

Namun, Obrador tidak bisa mencalonkan diri lagi karena konstitusi Meskiko hanya membatasi masa jabatan presiden hanya satu kali yakni dalam periode enam tahun.

Pemilu minggu ini menghasilkan kemenangan gemilang bagi Claudia Sheinbaum, yang menjadi presiden perempuan pertama di Meksiko.

Mantan walikota Mexico City berusia 61 tahun itu juga mengucapkan terima kasih kepada Xochiti Galvez, saingan utamanya, karena mengakui kekalahan.

Hasil resmi dari National Electoral Institute menunjukkan bahwa Sheinbaum memperoleh sekitar 58% suara. Mengalahkan Jorge Alvarwez Maynez dan Xochiti Galvez.

Keberhasilan Sheinbaum digambarkan oleh Presiden Meksiko Andres Manual Lopez Obrador sebagai "peristiwa bersejarah".

Negara tersebut memilih presiden perempuan pertamanya pada saat kejahatan berbasis gender dan kekerasan kriminal meningkat di Meksiko.

Salah satu janji kampanye Sheinbaum adalah menerapkan pendekatan mantan presiden tersebut dalam memberantas kejahatan di Meksiko hingga ke sumbernya.

Claudia Sheinbaum jadi presiden wanita pertama Meksiko usai meraih suara terbanyak dalam pemilihan umum 2024 negara tersebut, berdasarkan hasil awal yang dirilis Institut Pemilihan Umum Nasional (NEI) Meksiko.

Musim pemilihan umum di Meksiko kali ini telah menjadi yang paling kelam dan mematikan dalam sejarah modernnya. 

Wali Kota Cotija di Meksiko barat adalah yang terakhir tewas pada Senin (4/6/2024). Sehingga tercatat sudah 38 politisi yang menjadi korban pembunuhan sejak akhir tahun lalu.

Pemerintah daerah mengumumkan, Wali Kota Cotija Yolanda Sanchez Figueroa dibunuh hanya 24 jam setelah Claudia Sheinbaum terpilih sebagai presiden perempuan pertama di Meksico. 

ğŸ—£ï¸ â€œPemerintah negara bagian Michoacan mengutuk pembunuhan Wali Kota Cotija, Yolanda Sanchez Figueroa," tulis kementerian dalam negeri regional di X.

Pembunuhan wali kota perempuan itu terjadi di tengah eforia kemenangan telak Sheinbaum yang sama-sama perempuan dengan harapan perubahan di negara yang dilanda kekerasan berbasis gender itu. 

Media lokal menyebutkan Sanchez, yang terpilih sebagai wali kota pada pemilu 2021, ditembak mati di jalan umum. Pihak berwenang belum memberikan rincian mengenai pembunuhan tersebut namun menyatakan bahwa operasi keamanan telah dilancarkan untuk menangkap para pelaku.

Kemenangan Claudia Sheinbaum sebagai presiden perempuan pertama Meksiko, dirayakan oleh para pendukungnya di Mexico City. Mereka mengibarkan bendera Meksiko, dan merayakan kemenangan kandidat dari partai berkuasa, Morena. Dari sekitar 78% perolehan suara, Sheinbaum memperoleh raihan sekitar 59% suara, atau 2x kali lebih banyak dari pesaing terdekatnya Xochitl Galvez, yang memperoleh sekitar 28% suara. Kemenangan bagi Sheinbaum merupakan sebuah langkah besar bagi Meksiko. Claudia Sheinbaum adalah seorang politikus dan ilmuwan meksiko, yang sebelumnya menjabat sebagai Wali Kota Mexico City sejak 5 Desember 2018.

Claudia Sheinbaum akan menjadi presiden wanita pertama Meksiko usai meraih suara terbanyak dalam pemilihan umum 2024 negara tersebut, berdasarkan hasil awal yang dirilis Institut Pemilihan Umum Nasional (NEI) Meksiko.

Badan pemilihan umum Meksiko tersebut memulai proses hitung awal setelah lebih dari 170 ribu TPS ditutup pukul 6 sore waktu setempat, Minggu (2/6).

Berdasarkan hitung cepat, Sheinbaum meraih lebih dari 58 persen suara, mengalahkan calon presiden perempuan lain, Xochitl Galvez Ruiz yang mendapat hanya sekitar 26,6--28,6 persen suara, dan Jorge Alvares Maynes yang mendapat 9,9--10,8 persen suara.

Claudia Sheinbaum akan menjadi presiden wanita pertama Meksiko usai meraih suara terbanyak dalam pemilihan umum 2024 negara tersebut, berdasarkan hasil awal yang dirilis Institut Pemilihan Umum Nasional (NEI) Meksiko. Badan pemilihan umum Meksiko tersebut memulai proses hitung awal setelah lebih dari 170 ribu TPS ditutup pukul 6 sore waktu setempat, Minggu (2/6/2024).

Pemilihan Umum (Pemilu) tahun ini menjadi yang paling berdarah sepanjang sejarah Meksiko. Pasalnya, terdapat beberapa kandidat pejabat lokal yang dibunuh oleh berbagai kelompok oposisi hingga mencapai 37 korban jiwa. Menurut laporanÂ Reuters, angka kematian ini merupakan yang tertinggi sepanjang sejarah pemilu Meksiko, setelah pada 2021 mencapai 36 orang.

Kasus penyerangan terhadap pejabat politik Mexico ini menjadi isu utama di tengah-tengah masa kekuasaan Presiden Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador. Pihak oposisi turut disebut sebagai pelaku tragis tersebut demi memperjuangkan perubahan di negara tersebut. Peneliti Integralia, Armando Vargas mengungkap bahwa kekerasan bisa menjadi salah satu sarana yang digunakan dalam pemilu tahun ini.

Vargas juga melihat terdapat 828 percobaan pembunuhan terhadap kandidat politik. Angka tersebut naik dari 749 serangan sejak Senin (20/5/2024). Namun, analis keamanan mengatakan upaya pembunuhan tersebut sebagian besar berkaitan dengan kelompok kartel narkoba. Mereka disebut ingin memengaruhi pemilu lokal melalui cara kekerasan.

Claudia Sheinbaum sebagai kandidat yang memenangi pemilu 2024 Meksiko juga mengungkapkan keseriusannya untuk membasmi kekerasan di Meksiko sampai ke akar-akarnya. Hal itu menjadi salah satu janji kampanye Sheinbaum selama menjadi calon presiden Meksiko pada tahun ini.

President Bola Tinubu has extended heartfelt congratulations to Ms. Claudia Sheinbaum on her historic victory as the first female President of Mexico. Sheinbaum's landslide win marks a monumental moment in Mexico's history, being the first woman to lead the country since its independence in 1821. In a statement released by Media Adviser Ajuri Ngelale, Tinubu praised Sheinbaum's election as a significant advancement for women's voices in government, breaking political barriers and underscoring the crucial role women play in shaping global decisions.

Tinubu expressed his joy on behalf of the Nigerian government and its citizens, celebrating this milestone with the people of Mexico. He emphasized the importance of women not just participating but leading in governmental roles. Furthermore, Tinubu called for the strengthening of bilateral relations between Nigeria and Mexico, highlighting areas of mutual interest and cooperation.

Read the full article on Thisdaylive. Click the link in our bio. #ClaudiaSheinbaum #HistoricElection #WomenInLeadership #PresidentTinubu #Thisdaylive

JosÃ© Doroteo Arango ArÃ¡mbula, tambiÃ©n conocido como Francisco Villa naciÃ³ un 5 de junio pero de 1878, en San Juan del RÃ­o, Durango.
Fue un revolucionario mexicano que liderÃ³, junto con Emiliano Zapata, el sector agrarista en la RevoluciÃ³n Mexicana. Campesino pobre, huÃ©rfano y con escasa formaciÃ³n, cuando estallÃ³ la gesta heroÃ­ca de 1910, llevaba muchos aÃ±os fugitivo en las montaÃ±as a causa de un asesinato; dedicado al bandolerismo, gozaba de admiraciÃ³n y popularidad entre los campesinos por sus acciones contra los hacendados ricos.

Pancho Villa secundÃ³ de inmediato los planteamientos de Francisco I. Madero, que en su Plan de San Luis llamÃ³ a alzarse en armas, el 20 de noviembre de 1910, contra el rÃ©gimen del dictador  Porfirio DÃ­az, prometiendo a los campesinos la devoluciÃ³n de las tierras injustamente arrebatadas durante la prolongada dictadura porfirista (1876-1911), que habÃ­a reprimido duramente toda oposiciÃ³n polÃ­tica. 

Apodado el Centauro del Norte por sus correligionarios, Pancho Villa contribuyÃ³ con su ejÃ©rcito al rÃ¡pido triunfo de la RevoluciÃ³n, que en apenas seis meses logrÃ³ expulsar del poder y del paÃ­s a Porfirio DÃ­az (1911).

Pero despuÃ©s de la victoria de esta segunda revoluciÃ³n, Villa y Zapata se sintieron defraudados por Carranza, y volvieron a tomar las armas, ahora contra Ã©l. Esta vez la suerte militar no estuvo de su parte: en 1915 el general carrancista Ãlvaro ObregÃ³n derrotÃ³ a los villistas, afianzando a Venustiano Carranza en la presidencia (1915-1920).

Perdido desde entonces su poder polÃ­tico y militar, Villa fue vilmente asesinado en 1923.

#Diplomatique ğŸ”®ğŸŒ

On June 2, 2024, Claudia Sheinbaum, the candidate of the governing Morena party, made history becoming Mexico's first woman elected president. After the electoral authorities released the first preliminary results, Sheinbaum took the stage to thank voters and emphasized the significance of the moment for gender equality in a country known for machismo: â€œFor the first time in 200 years of the Republic, there will be a woman president and she will be transformative.â€â 
â 
But as her supporters celebrate the groundbreaking achievement, the question remains what does transformative mean to Sheinbaum, who will take office in October: will her presidency bring change or will it just be a continuation of President AndrÃ©s Manuel LÃ³pez Obradorâ€™s (AMLO) policies?â 
â 
In the US, where few national commentators pay close attention to Mexican politics, the reaction has been one of genuine buzz. In Mexico, the view is much more nuanced. Mexican women have recognized the symbolism of a woman occupying the highest political office, but some are skeptical. Sheinbaumâ€™s identification with AMLO, who has had a fraught relationship with the women's movement and hasn't done enough to address gender violence, and the way she distanced herself from young activists as Head of Government of Mexico City, calling their protests â€œprovocationsâ€ that sought a violent answer from the government to get more attention, has concerned many. â 
â 
Still, many believe it's worth applauding that Sheinbaum won the presidency with a margin that has not been seen in Mexico since the 1980s. Her win represents a tremendous step forward for gender equality, and her presidency holds the potential for progress in social justice, the fight against climate change, sustainability, and an economy that works for all. Sheinbaumâ€™s affiliation with AMLO allowed for a placid campaign where the outcome was known months before the election was held. Now it will be crucial for her to show she can establish her own political identity and a distinct agenda. â

Kampanye pemilu 2024 disebut kampanye paling penuh dengan aksi kekerasan sepanjang sejarah Meksiko. Adapun kawasan yang disebut sebagai tempat yang paling berbahaya dan kejam untuk mendulang suara adalah di Negara Bagian Guerrero.
.
Wali Kota Cotija di Meksiko barat adalah yang terakhir tewas pada Senin (4/6/2024) sehingga tercatat sudah 38 politisi yang menjadi korban pembunuhan sejak akhir tahun lalu.
.
Menurut laporan sejak September 2023 hingga menjelang Pemilu 2024 pada Minggu (2/6), setidaknya ada 30 lebih politisi tewas, 77 menerima ancaman, dan 11 lainnya diculik.
.
Masa-masa pemilu di Meksiko rawan terjadi pembunuhan para politisi. Para pemilu paruh waktu tahun 2021, angkanya mencapai 36 kandidat dibunuh. Sementara angka tahun ini melampaui angka tersebut.
.
Kekerasan yang terus terjadi sekali lagi menyoroti isu kejahatan di negara bagian Amerika Utara tersebut. Pihak oposisi memanfaatkan tingginya tingkat kejahatan secara politik untuk menantang Partai Morena pimpinan Presiden Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador yang akan segera lengser.
.
Di Meksiko, kartel narkoba diketahui kerap meluncurkan pembunuhan politikus untuk menguasai kepolisian setempat atau memeras pemerintah daerah.
.
Para analis mengaitkan lonjakan kekerasan ini dengan terjalinnya kartel narkoba yang kuat dan pemerintah daerah yang korup, sehingga menimbulkan risiko besar bagi para calon kandidat.
_

Un contesto nel quale le violenze legate a gruppi armati criminali, spesso connessi ai cartelli del narcotraffico, attuano un vero e proprio contropotere, assumendo una valenza para istituzionale.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi congratulated Mexico's first President-elect Claudia Sheinbaum on Thursday, and said that it is a momentous occassion for the country's people.
In a post on X, PM Modi wrote, "Congratulations to @Claudiashein, Mexico's first woman President-elect! This is a momentous occasion for the people of Mexico and a tribute to the great leadership of President @lopezobrador_as well."

"Looking forward to continued collaboration and shared progress," he added.

Climate scientist and former mayor of Mexico City, Claudia Sheinbaum, was elected as the first woman to be elected as President of Mexico after the June 2 elections. She will also be the first Jewish leader of Jewish heritage to hold the office.

Sheinbaum (61) received nearly 58% of the vote, according to preliminary results from the Mexican electoral office, as per a report by The Politico.

Las evidencias de corrupciÃ³n, violencia, desastre fiscal y la adherencia a polÃ­ticas caducas como la estatizaciÃ³n de servicios o el mantenimiento de los privilegios del magisterio mediocre que condena al analfabetismo bruto y sumiso al grueso de la poblaciÃ³n, pueden ser ignoradas y neutralizadas con el sirirÃ­ simplista de que los gobiernos anteriores de centro o de centroderecha eran o serÃ¡n igual de malos.
Presiden Perempuan

Claudia Sheinbaum, the former mayor of Mexico City with a PhD in energy engineering, is also the first Jewish person to lead Mexico, where 70% of the population is Catholic.

This was the largest election in Mexicoâ€™s history, with more than 98 million citizens registered to vote. Nearly 20,000 elected positions were being contested, including the presidency, both chambers of Congress and thousands of local seats.

It was also the most violent election, with more than 30 politicians killed.

The new president will now face two major challenges: confronting the rampant violence in Mexican society and increasing militarisation of public life, and the deterioration of checks and balances on executive power.

Sheinbaumâ€™s mentor, current President AndrÃ©s Manuel LÃ³pez Obrador, has not solved the first issue, and has significantly worsened the second.

#Review - Legacy is on the table in this powerful novel about art, an artist, and the art of memory.

WHAT IS IT? Moments before the artist Anita de Monte died in 1985, her career was reaching new heights. Her husband, acclaimed artist Jack Martin, might have been jealous. He might have been furious. He might have pushed her. But it doesnâ€™t matter. Because the history books continue to celebrate Jack and write off Anita as a footnote in his history. But in 1998, an Art History student on her own rise, Raquel, stumbles into the world of Anita, a world so forgotten youâ€™d think someone was hiding her on purpose. As Raquel navigates her own challenges as a Latinx woman surrounded by an elitist, elusive community at Brown, she learns that Anitaâ€™s journey might have both the same motivation and consequences as her own. 

DID I LIKE IT? Really liked it! XÃ³chitl GonzÃ¡lezâ€™s sophomore novel is hardly a slump, and is probably my favorite Reeseâ€™s Book Club pick in a very long time. Following up the gutsy, gorgeous OLGA DIES DREAMING would be no easy feat, but ANITA DE MONTE LAUGHS LAST succeeds by doubling down on OLGAâ€™s winning formula. It dives headfirst into a cultural institution that can be complicated for anyone but Men (Art History). It examines this institution thoughtfully through a deep appreciation for heritage â€” in this case, the Cuban-American experience and the working class New York experience. And it does this by giving us a heroine to root for, one who is making mistakes that you want to shake her to stop from making. It means you end up with a heartfelt, whole meal of a novel that wins on rich plot and character work. Full review on my Goodreads to hear me rave and (good) rage about it more! I think ANITA DE MONTE LAUGHS LAST will be one of those novels that will be hard to forget once you read it.

Mexican Election Reveals Key Social Trends
Top of mind for many lower-income voters was the economy.
One of the most valuable things about elections is what they reveal about the social forces in a country. In Mexicoâ€™s June 2 presidential elections, economic concerns were a major factor in how voters decided to cast their ballots, particularly among lower-income individuals. President-elect Claudia Sheinbaum won widespread support among lower-income households and individuals who have occupations with lower earning potential. She also performed well in the south where economic conditions are poorer than in the north.
However, certain issues resonated across the political and geographical spectrum. Security, for example, was a key consideration for many voters throughout the country. Itâ€™s also important to note that these results reflect the attitudes of only 58 percent of Mexican voters who actually cast ballots, about 5 points lower than the voter turnout in most elections over the past 24 years.
